title: Judges Chapter 11 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Judges chapter 11 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Judges Chapter 11 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Judges Chapter 11.

questions.question: Who was Jephthah's mother described as in Judges 11:1?
options: A harlot
A queen
A prophetess
A widow
questions.correctAnswer: A harlot
questions.explanation: Judges 11:1 states that Jephthah was the son of a harlot.

questions.question: Why did Jephthah's brothers thrust him out of their father's house according to Judges 11:2?
options: Because he was the son of a strange woman
Because he stole from them
Because he was a coward
Because he refused to fight
questions.correctAnswer: Because he was the son of a strange woman
questions.explanation: Judges 11:2 explains that Jephthah's brothers said he should not inherit because he was the son of a strange woman.

questions.question: Where did Jephthah flee to after being cast out by his brethren?
options: The land of Tob
The land of Moab
The wilderness of Sinai
The city of Jericho
questions.correctAnswer: The land of Tob
questions.explanation: Judges 11:3 states that Jephthah fled to the land of Tob.

questions.question: Who made war against Israel as mentioned in Judges 11:4?
options: The children of Ammon
The Philistines
The Moabites
The Edomites
questions.correctAnswer: The children of Ammon
questions.explanation: Judges 11:4 says that the children of Ammon made war against Israel.

questions.question: What did the elders of Gilead want Jephthah to do according to Judges 11:6?
options: Be their captain to fight the children of Ammon
Become king of Israel
Build a wall around Gilead
Make peace with the children of Ammon
questions.correctAnswer: Be their captain to fight the children of Ammon
questions.explanation: Judges 11:6 shows the elders asking Jephthah to be their captain to fight against the children of Ammon.

questions.question: True or False: Jephthah immediately accepted the elders’ offer without any conditions.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 11:9 shows Jephthah asking if the LORD will deliver the Ammonites before he agrees to be their head.

questions.question: What did Jephthah do before going to fight the children of Ammon according to Judges 11:11?
options: Uttered all his words before the LORD in Mizpeh
Built an altar
Fasted for seven days
Anointed himself with oil
questions.correctAnswer: Uttered all his words before the LORD in Mizpeh
questions.explanation: Judges 11:11 states that Jephthah uttered all his words before the LORD in Mizpeh.

questions.question: What was the reason given by the king of the children of Ammon for making war against Israel in Judges 11:13?
options: Israel took away his land from Arnon to Jabbok
Israel refused to pay tribute
Israel allied with Moab
Israel desecrated their temple
questions.correctAnswer: Israel took away his land from Arnon to Jabbok
questions.explanation: Judges 11:13 states the king of Ammon claimed Israel took his land from Arnon even to Jabbok and Jordan.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Judges 11:30: 'And Jephthah vowed a vow unto the LORD, and said, If thou shalt without fail deliver the children of Ammon into mine hands, then it shall be, that ________.'
options: whatsoever cometh forth of the doors of my house to meet me shall surely be the LORD'S
I will build a temple to the LORD
I will give a tenth of all my spoils to the Levites
I will never go to war again
questions.correctAnswer: whatsoever cometh forth of the doors of my house to meet me shall surely be the LORD'S
questions.explanation: Judges 11:30-31 shows Jephthah's vow that whatever comes out of his house to meet him will be the LORD's and offered as a burnt offering.

questions.question: True or False: The LORD delivered the children of Ammon into Jephthah's hands as stated in Judges 11:32.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 11:32 confirms that the LORD delivered the children of Ammon into Jephthah's hands.

questions.question: How many cities did Jephthah smite from Aroer to Minnith according to Judges 11:33?
options: Twenty
Ten
Thirty
Five
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty
questions.explanation: Judges 11:33 says Jephthah smote twenty cities from Aroer to Minnith.

questions.question: Who came out to meet Jephthah when he returned home after the battle according to Judges 11:34?
options: His daughter
His wife
His mother
His brother
questions.correctAnswer: His daughter
questions.explanation: Judges 11:34 states that Jephthah's daughter came out to meet him.

questions.question: What was Jephthah's reaction when he saw his daughter coming out to meet him?
options: He rent his clothes and lamented
He rejoiced and praised God
He ignored her
He asked her to prepare a feast
questions.correctAnswer: He rent his clothes and lamented
questions.explanation: Judges 11:35 says Jephthah rent his clothes and exclaimed 'Alas, my daughter!' because of his vow.

questions.question: True or False: Jephthah's daughter asked for two months to mourn her virginity before her father fulfilled his vow.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 11:37-38 shows Jephthah's daughter asking for two months to bewail her virginity on the mountains.

questions.question: For how many days did the daughters of Israel go yearly to lament the daughter of Jephthah according to Judges 11:40?
options: Four days
Seven days
One day
Ten days
questions.correctAnswer: Four days
questions.explanation: Judges 11:40 states that the daughters of Israel lamented the daughter of Jephthah four days each year.

medium.title: Judges Chapter 11 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Judges Chapter 11 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with rejection from their family because of their faith. Based on Judges 11, what biblical truth would you share about perseverance and trust in God?
options: God can use even those rejected by their family for His purposes.
Family rejection means God has abandoned you.
Avoid all conflict by hiding your faith from family.
Success depends only on human effort, not God's help.
questions.correctAnswer: God can use even those rejected by their family for His purposes.
questions.explanation: Jephthah was rejected by his brothers (Judges 11:2-3) but God used him mightily to deliver Israel (Judges 11:29-32). This teaches us perseverance and trust in God's plan despite rejection.

questions.question: How does Jephthah’s response to the elders of Gilead teach about humility and readiness to serve despite past wrongs?
options: He questioned their motives but agreed to serve if God granted victory.
He immediately accepted without question.
He refused because of past rejection.
He demanded payment before helping.
questions.correctAnswer: He questioned their motives but agreed to serve if God granted victory.
questions.explanation: Jephthah asked why they sought him now after expelling him and set a condition that if God delivered Ammon, he would lead them (Judges 11:7-10). This shows humility and dependence on God’s guidance.

questions.question: What practical lesson about honoring vows and integrity can we learn from Jephthah’s vow to the Lord?
options: We must be careful with our promises to God and keep them faithfully.
It is acceptable to break vows if circumstances change.
Vows to God are only symbolic and need not be fulfilled.
Making vows to God guarantees success without effort.
questions.correctAnswer: We must be careful with our promises to God and keep them faithfully.
questions.explanation: Jephthah vowed to offer as a burnt offering whatever came out of his house if God delivered Ammon (Judges 11:30-31) and honored it despite the cost (Judges 11:39). This emphasizes integrity and seriousness in vows.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by trials and is tempted to give up. Based on Judges 11, what biblical truth encourages perseverance through trials?
options: The Spirit of the LORD can empower us to overcome great challenges.
Trials are a sign God has forsaken us.
We should avoid trials by isolating ourselves.
Victory depends solely on human strength.
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit of the LORD can empower us to overcome great challenges.
questions.explanation: The Spirit of the LORD came upon Jephthah before battle (Judges 11:29), enabling victory over Ammon (Judges 11:32-33). This shows God’s empowering presence amid trials.

questions.question: How does Jephthah’s dialogue with the king of Ammon teach about honesty and speaking truth in conflict?
options: Jephthah honestly explained Israel’s claim to the land with historical facts.
Jephthah avoided confrontation and agreed to all demands.
Jephthah lied to gain an advantage.
Jephthah remained silent and sent no messengers.
questions.correctAnswer: Jephthah honestly explained Israel’s claim to the land with historical facts.
questions.explanation: Jephthah sent messengers recounting Israel’s history and rightful possession of the land (Judges 11:12-27), demonstrating integrity and truthfulness even in conflict.

questions.question: What does Jephthah’s willingness to lead after being rejected teach about forgiveness and reconciliation in leadership?
options: Leaders should be willing to serve even those who wronged them if God calls.
One should never forgive or work with those who have hurt them.
Leadership requires revenge against past enemies.
Only those with perfect pasts can lead.
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders should be willing to serve even those who wronged them if God calls.
questions.explanation: Despite being expelled, Jephthah accepted leadership to save his people (Judges 11:2-11), teaching forgiveness and serving others selflessly.

questions.question: How does Jephthah’s vow and its fulfillment instruct us about the seriousness of promises made to God in our spiritual disciplines?
options: Promises to God must be honored even when difficult.
Vows can be ignored if inconvenient.
God does not require us to keep vows.
Vows are optional and have no spiritual weight.
questions.correctAnswer: Promises to God must be honored even when difficult.
questions.explanation: Jephthah fulfilled his vow despite the personal cost (Judges 11:35-39), showing the importance of faithfulness in spiritual commitments.

questions.question: True or False: Jephthah’s leadership was initiated only because he sought power and revenge against his brothers.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jephthah was called by the elders to lead because of his valor and God’s Spirit upon him, not just personal ambition or revenge (Judges 11:3, 5-6, 29).

questions.question: True or False: The daughters of Israel commemorated Jephthah’s daughter annually for four days as a custom after his vow was fulfilled.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: After Jephthah fulfilled his vow with his daughter, the daughters of Israel lamented for her yearly for four days (Judges 11:39-40).

questions.question: How does Jephthah’s prayer and vow before battle teach about faith and dependence on God in times of decision?
options: Jephthah sought God’s help and made a vow trusting Him for victory.
Jephthah relied solely on his own strength without prayer.
Jephthah ignored God’s guidance and acted impulsively.
Jephthah made no vows or prayers before battle.
questions.correctAnswer: Jephthah sought God’s help and made a vow trusting Him for victory.
questions.explanation: Before battle, Jephthah vowed to the LORD trusting for deliverance (Judges 11:29-31), showing faith and dependence on God’s power.

questions.question: A believer faces opposition from neighbors over their faith. Based on Judges 11, what should they remember about God's sovereignty over land and people?
options: God gives and takes possession of land and people according to His will.
Possession of land depends only on human strength.
God has no interest in earthly territories.
Conflict over land is always unjustified.
questions.correctAnswer: God gives and takes possession of land and people according to His will.
questions.explanation: Jephthah reminded Ammon that God dispossessed Amorites and gives land to whoever He chooses (Judges 11:23-24), illustrating God’s sovereign authority.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jephthah was described as a mighty man of _______.
options: valor
faith
wisdom
wealth
questions.correctAnswer: valor
questions.explanation: The chapter opens calling Jephthah a mighty man of valor, emphasizing his courage and strength (Judges 11:1).

questions.question: How can Jephthah’s story encourage believers to maintain integrity and honesty when facing accusations or misunderstandings?
options: Jephthah clearly stated his case and reasons for his actions to the elders and enemies.
Jephthah avoided all difficult conversations.
Jephthah retaliated with lies and deceit.
Jephthah ignored accusations and left the land.
questions.correctAnswer: Jephthah clearly stated his case and reasons for his actions to the elders and enemies.
questions.explanation: Jephthah confronted the elders about their previous rejection (Judges 11:7) and gave a reasoned defense to the Ammonites (Judges 11:12-27), showing integrity in communication.

questions.question: What does the response of Jephthah’s daughter teach about obedience and submission to God's will even in difficult circumstances?
options: She accepted her father’s vow and asked for time to mourn before submission.
She rebelled and refused to honor the vow.
She fled and hid to avoid the vow.
She sought to negotiate a new vow.
questions.correctAnswer: She accepted her father’s vow and asked for time to mourn before submission.
questions.explanation: Jephthah’s daughter accepted the vow (Judges 11:36) and requested two months to mourn her virginity (Judges 11:37-38), showing willing submission to God’s will.

questions.question: What does the gathering of vain men to Jephthah in the land of Tob illustrate about God’s use of imperfect people for His purposes?
options: God can use even those considered worthless or outcast to achieve His plans.
Only perfect people can serve God effectively.
God rejects those with sinful backgrounds.
Strength comes only from noble birth.
questions.correctAnswer: God can use even those considered worthless or outcast to achieve His plans.
questions.explanation: Jephthah fled to Tob where vain men gathered to him (Judges 11:3), and God used him for deliverance, showing God’s grace to imperfect people.

hard.title: Judges Chapter 11 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Judges Chapter 11.

questions.question: What is the significance of Jephthah being described as "the son of a harlot" in Judges 11:1, in terms of Israelite social and legal context?
options: It signifies his exclusion from inheritance and leadership due to social stigma
It marks him as a priestly figure in Israel
It indicates he was a foreigner from the land of Tob
It emphasizes his royal lineage and entitlement
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies his exclusion from inheritance and leadership due to social stigma
questions.explanation: Judges 11:1 and 11:2 show Jephthah was rejected by his half-brothers because of his mother's status, which culturally excluded him from inheritance rights and leadership, highlighting social stigmas in ancient Israel.

questions.question: In Judges 11:3, Jephthah gathers "vain men" to him when he fled to the land of Tob. What might this phrase imply about the type of followers he attracted, considering the socio-political context of the time?
options: They were likely outcasts or mercenaries without strong tribal loyalty
They were priests and religious leaders
They were members of the royal family
They were peaceful farmers and priests
questions.correctAnswer: They were likely outcasts or mercenaries without strong tribal loyalty
questions.explanation: The phrase "vain men" (Hebrew: 'empty men') suggests those without honor or tribal ties, possibly mercenaries or social outcasts who followed Jephthah, reflecting the fragmentation and social unrest during the Judges period.

questions.question: How does the elders of Gilead's approach to Jephthah in Judges 11:5-6 reflect the political and military realities of Israel during the period of the Judges?
options: They sought a capable military leader despite past enmity due to external threat
They wanted to negotiate peace with the Ammonites through Jephthah
They aimed to exile Jephthah permanently
They wished to crown Jephthah as king of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: They sought a capable military leader despite past enmity due to external threat
questions.explanation: The elders' request in Judges 11:5-6 shows pragmatic leadership choices in times of war, overlooking personal grievances to face the Ammonite threat, a common theme in the Judges era's decentralized tribal leadership.

questions.question: Jephthah's conditional acceptance of leadership in Judges 11:9-10 involves invoking the LORD as a witness. What does this reveal about the role of divine authority in Israelite leadership and covenant-making?
options: It shows that divine sanction was essential for legitimate leadership and agreements
It indicates a rejection of divine involvement in human affairs
It implies that Jephthah was a prophet
It reflects a secular political agreement
questions.correctAnswer: It shows that divine sanction was essential for legitimate leadership and agreements
questions.explanation: By invoking the LORD as a witness (Judges 11:9-10), Jephthah and the elders affirm that leadership and covenants require divine approval, illustrating Israel's theocratic values where God’s role legitimizes human authority.

questions.question: In Judges 11:12-28, Jephthah negotiates with the Ammonite king by recounting Israel's historical journey and territorial claims. How does this speech function as a form of ancient Near Eastern diplomatic rhetoric?
options: It asserts Israel's lawful claim based on divine mandate and historical precedent
It offers to share the disputed land peacefully
It threatens immediate military action without justification
It requests tribute from the Ammonite king
questions.correctAnswer: It asserts Israel's lawful claim based on divine mandate and historical precedent
questions.explanation: Jephthah’s speech (Judges 11:12-28) uses historical narrative and divine sanction to legitimize Israel’s territorial rights, a common diplomatic strategy in the ancient Near East to justify claims and avoid conflict.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of Jephthah’s vow in Judges 11:30-31, especially in light of Hebrew sacrificial traditions and the covenantal context?
options: It shows a tragic misuse of vows, emphasizing the dangers of rash promises to God
It is an example of a typical peace treaty offering
It indicates Jephthah's role as a priest
It demonstrates a ritual of purification after battle
questions.correctAnswer: It shows a tragic misuse of vows, emphasizing the dangers of rash promises to God
questions.explanation: Jephthah’s vow (Judges 11:30-31) to offer whatever greets him reflects the seriousness of vows in Israel but also warns of the destructive consequences of impulsive promises, highlighting the tension between personal vows and divine will.

questions.question: The narrative structure surrounding Jephthah’s vow and its fulfillment (Judges 11:30-40) can be seen as a literary chiasm. Which of the following best describes this chiastic structure?
options: A: Vow made; B: Battle won; B': Daughter meets him; A': Daughter’s lament and fulfillment of vow
A: Battle preparations; B: Prayer; C: Vow; B': Victory; A': Celebration
A: Jephthah’s exile; B: Gathering followers; C: Battle; D: Victory
A: Jephthah’s rejection; B: Reconciliation; C: Victory; D: Coronation
questions.correctAnswer: A: Vow made; B: Battle won; B': Daughter meets him; A': Daughter’s lament and fulfillment of vow
questions.explanation: The narrative in Judges 11:30-40 forms a chiastic pattern emphasizing the vow’s gravity and its tragic outcome, framing the battle victory with the vow and its human cost, enhancing thematic depth.

questions.question: Considering Judges 11:34-40, how does the story of Jephthah's daughter prefigure or contrast with other biblical narratives involving sacrificial dedication of children, such as the story of Hannah or Abraham and Isaac?
options: It contrasts by ending in actual sacrifice rather than divine intervention
It parallels with a miraculous rescue from death
It shows a typical joyful dedication of children to God
It illustrates a royal consecration ceremony
questions.correctAnswer: It contrasts by ending in actual sacrifice rather than divine intervention
questions.explanation: Unlike Abraham’s story where God intervenes (Genesis 22), Jephthah’s daughter is sacrificed, highlighting the tragic consequences of vows and raising theological questions about human sacrifice in Israel’s history.

questions.question: The repeated mention of geographic locations such as Arnon, Jabbok, and Jordan in Judges 11:13-24 serves what purpose in the narrative's historical and theological argument?
options: It establishes Israel’s territorial boundaries and divine right to the land
It describes trade routes used by Israel
It lists places of Israelite exile
It records locations of ancient temples
questions.correctAnswer: It establishes Israel’s territorial boundaries and divine right to the land
questions.explanation: By citing these specific landmarks, Jephthah asserts Israel’s God-given boundaries, reinforcing the legitimacy of Israel’s possession against Ammonite claims (Judges 11:13-24).

questions.question: How does Judges 11:29 describe the Spirit of the LORD coming upon Jephthah, and what is the significance of this motif across the book of Judges and broader biblical tradition?
options: It signifies divine empowerment for leadership and victory, a recurring theme for judges
It marks Jephthah as a prophet exclusively
It indicates a permanent possession of the Spirit
It shows a symbolic cleansing ritual
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies divine empowerment for leadership and victory, a recurring theme for judges
questions.explanation: The Spirit of the LORD coming upon Jephthah (Judges 11:29) is a hallmark of the judges’ divine calling and empowerment for deliverance, reflecting God's active role in Israel’s leadership.

questions.question: What cultural practice is indicated by the daughters of Israel lamenting for Jephthah’s daughter annually as described in Judges 11:40, and how does this reflect ancient Israelite memory and mourning traditions?
options: It reflects a communal ritual of mourning and remembrance for tragic sacrifice
It was a festival of thanksgiving
It commemorated a military victory
It was a wedding celebration
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects a communal ritual of mourning and remembrance for tragic sacrifice
questions.explanation: The annual lament (Judges 11:40) indicates a ritualized cultural memory preserving the tragedy of Jephthah’s vow, showing how Israelite society commemorated grief and loss collectively.

questions.question: True or False: Jephthah’s negotiation with the Ammonite king includes a detailed recounting of Israel’s failed attempts to pass through Edom and Moab, emphasizing Israel’s respect for territorial boundaries.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 11:17-18 recounts Israel’s requests to pass through Edom and Moab, both denied, showing Israel’s respect for territorial boundaries and justifying their claim against Ammon.

questions.question: What literary device is most evident in Judges 11:27 where Jephthah calls upon the LORD as judge to arbitrate between Israel and Ammon, and what is its effect?
options: Appeal to divine justice, reinforcing the legitimacy of Israel’s cause
Personification of the land
Irony to mock the Ammonites
Metaphor for military strength
questions.correctAnswer: Appeal to divine justice, reinforcing the legitimacy of Israel’s cause
questions.explanation: Jephthah’s invocation of the LORD as judge in Judges 11:27 employs an appeal to divine authority, framing the conflict as a just cause under God’s adjudication.

questions.question: How does the account of Jephthah and the Ammonites in Judges 11 reflect the broader theme of Israel’s cyclical faithfulness and apostasy found throughout the book of Judges?
options: Jephthah’s rise and victory come amid social rejection, showing God’s use of imperfect leaders to deliver Israel
It depicts a perfect leader who never fails
It shows Israel’s unbroken obedience to God
It records Israel’s conquest of Canaan
questions.correctAnswer: Jephthah’s rise and victory come amid social rejection, showing God’s use of imperfect leaders to deliver Israel
questions.explanation: Jephthah’s story illustrates the Judges pattern: Israel’s distress, God raising a flawed deliverer, and temporary peace, reflecting the cyclical nature of faithfulness and apostasy (Judges 11 overall).

questions.question: In Judges 11:24, Jephthah contrasts the gods Chemosh and the LORD. What does this reveal about Israelite monotheism and their view of territorial possession in the ancient Near East?
options: It asserts that land possession is granted by respective deities, highlighting exclusive divine sovereignty
It promotes religious syncretism
It denies any divine role in land possession
It accepts all gods as equal owners of land
questions.correctAnswer: It asserts that land possession is granted by respective deities, highlighting exclusive divine sovereignty
questions.explanation: Jephthah’s statement in 11:24 shows Israel’s belief that the LORD is the sovereign grantor of their land, contrasting with Chemosh’s claim over Moab, reinforcing monotheistic territorial theology.

theological.title: Judges Chapter 11 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Judges Chapter 11 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What aspect of Jephthah's background caused his half-brothers to reject him and deny him inheritance?
options: He was the son of a harlot
He was physically weak
He was a foreigner from Egypt
He worshipped other gods
questions.correctAnswer: He was the son of a harlot
questions.explanation: Jephthah was rejected by his brothers because he was the son of a harlot, which they used to disinherit him (Judges 11:1-2). This illustrates the biblical theme of human rejection despite God's calling, as also seen in Moses' exile (Exodus 2:11-15) and David's humble beginnings (1 Samuel 16:1-13). Yet God often raises the rejected for His purposes (1 Corinthians 1:27-29).

questions.question: Why did the elders of Gilead seek Jephthah's leadership during the Ammonite war?
options: Because they needed a mighty warrior to lead them
Because Jephthah was the rightful king
Because Jephthah was the only surviving son
Because Jephthah had diplomatic skills
questions.correctAnswer: Because they needed a mighty warrior to lead them
questions.explanation: The elders sought Jephthah because they recognized his valor and capability to lead in battle against Ammon (Judges 11:5-6). This reflects God's sovereign use of unlikely leaders (Judges 6:12; 1 Samuel 17:32-50) and the biblical principle that God equips the called for His mission (Ephesians 6:10-18).

questions.question: What condition did Jephthah set before accepting leadership over Gilead?
options: That the LORD deliver the Ammonites into his hands
That he be made king immediately
That his inheritance be restored
That the people give him a large army
questions.correctAnswer: That the LORD deliver the Ammonites into his hands
questions.explanation: Jephthah stipulated that if God granted him victory over the Ammonites, then he would become their leader (Judges 11:9-10). This underscores the doctrine of divine sovereignty in salvation and deliverance (Psalm 20:7; Romans 8:31), emphasizing trust in God's providential power rather than human strength.

questions.question: How did Jephthah justify Israel's possession of the land in response to the Ammonite king's claim?
options: By recounting Israel's peaceful request to pass through Edom and Moab
By threatening military conquest
By accusing the Ammonites of idolatry
By claiming a covenant with Abraham
questions.correctAnswer: By recounting Israel's peaceful request to pass through Edom and Moab
questions.explanation: Jephthah argued that Israel never took land from Moab or Ammon but only from Amorites after peaceful passage was denied (Judges 11:16-18). This defense reflects the biblical principle of just war and God's providential granting of the land (Deuteronomy 2:1-8; Psalm 24:1), affirming God's role as the ultimate judge and disposer of nations.

questions.question: What theological principle is expressed in Jephthah's statement about Chemosh and the LORD regarding territorial possession?
options: That each god grants territory to their people and that Israel's God has dispossessed the Amorites
That all gods are equal in power
That the Ammonites were chosen by God
That war is unjustifiable
questions.correctAnswer: That each god grants territory to their people and that Israel's God has dispossessed the Amorites
questions.explanation: Jephthah acknowledged that Chemosh gave Moab their land, but argued that the LORD had dispossessed the Amorites for Israel (Judges 11:23-24). This reveals the biblical understanding of God's sovereign judgment over nations (Psalm 2:8-9; Isaiah 45:1) and the Lord as the ultimate possessor of the earth (Psalm 24:1).

questions.question: What was Jephthah's vow to the LORD before going into battle?
options: He vowed to offer as a burnt offering whatever came out of his house to meet him
He vowed to build a temple if victorious
He vowed to never marry
He vowed to give one-tenth of the spoils to the priests
questions.correctAnswer: He vowed to offer as a burnt offering whatever came out of his house to meet him
questions.explanation: Jephthah vowed that if the LORD gave him victory, he would dedicate whatever first came out of his house to greet him as a burnt offering (Judges 11:30-31). This tragic vow highlights the seriousness of vows to God (Ecclesiastes 5:4-5) and the dangers of rash promises, contrasting with Christ's perfect and sufficient sacrifice (Hebrews 10:10).

questions.question: How did the Spirit of the LORD influence Jephthah before the battle?
options: The Spirit came upon him, empowering and leading him to fight
The Spirit caused him to fear and flee
The Spirit gave him prophetic dreams
The Spirit told him to negotiate peace
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit came upon him, empowering and leading him to fight
questions.explanation: The Spirit of the LORD came on Jephthah, enabling his leadership and military success (Judges 11:29). This reflects the biblical doctrine of the Holy Spirit empowering God's servants (Judges 3:10; Acts 1:8), affirming the Spirit's role in equipping for service and fulfilling God's purposes.

questions.question: What was the outcome of Jephthah's battle against the children of Ammon?
options: He defeated them, subduing twenty cities with great slaughter
He was defeated and fled
He made a peace treaty
The war ended in a stalemate
questions.correctAnswer: He defeated them, subduing twenty cities with great slaughter
questions.explanation: Jephthah's forces defeated the Ammonites, capturing twenty cities and subduing them with great slaughter (Judges 11:32-33). This victory demonstrates God's faithfulness to deliver His people (Exodus 14:30; Joshua 10:40), showcasing divine justice and protection of Israel.

questions.question: What tragic event occurred upon Jephthah's return home after the victory?
options: His only daughter came out to meet him, fulfilling his vow
His wife had died
His sons had taken his inheritance
His enemies attacked his home
questions.correctAnswer: His only daughter came out to meet him, fulfilling his vow
questions.explanation: Jephthah's only daughter came out dancing to meet him, and due to his vow, he was grieved because he could not revoke it (Judges 11:34-35). This episode illustrates the consequences of rash vows (Ecclesiastes 5:2-6) and the cost of human sinfulness, foreshadowing the need for Christ's perfect atonement (Hebrews 7:27).

questions.question: How did Jephthah's daughter respond to her father's vow and impending sacrifice?
options: She accepted it and asked for two months to mourn her virginity
She pleaded for her life and fled
She protested and refused to obey
She sought help from the elders
questions.correctAnswer: She accepted it and asked for two months to mourn her virginity
questions.explanation: Jephthah's daughter accepted the vow and requested two months to mourn her virginity with her companions (Judges 11:36-37). Her willing submission reflects biblical themes of obedience and faithfulness amidst suffering (Job 1:21; Luke 22:42), pointing to trust in God's justice despite human tragedy.

questions.question: What lasting custom was established in Israel because of Jephthah's daughter's story?
options: Daughters of Israel lamented her for four days annually
A festival of victory was held each year
Men fasted on the anniversary of the battle
A temple was built in her honor
questions.correctAnswer: Daughters of Israel lamented her for four days annually
questions.explanation: A yearly four-day lamentation was observed by the daughters of Israel for Jephthah's daughter (Judges 11:40). This custom reflects the biblical practice of mourning and remembrance (2 Samuel 1:17-27), underscoring the communal recognition of loss and the somber realities of covenantal obligations.

questions.question: What does Jephthah's story teach about the consequences of human vows in relation to divine will?
options: That vows to God must be taken seriously and can carry severe consequences
That God always accepts human sacrifices
That vows can be made without any repercussions
That God disregards rash vows
questions.correctAnswer: That vows to God must be taken seriously and can carry severe consequences
questions.explanation: Jephthah's experience shows the gravity of making vows to God and the serious consequences if not carefully considered (Judges 11:30-39). Scripture elsewhere commands fulfilling vows (Numbers 30:2) but condemns human sacrifice (Leviticus 18:21), pointing ultimately to Christ's perfect sacrifice as the true fulfillment (Hebrews 10:5-10).

questions.question: How does Jephthah's leadership demonstrate God's use of flawed human agents in His salvation plan?
options: God empowers imperfect people like Jephthah to accomplish His purposes
Only perfect leaders are used by God
God avoids using those with questionable backgrounds
Human strength alone achieves victory
questions.correctAnswer: God empowers imperfect people like Jephthah to accomplish His purposes
questions.explanation: Jephthah, despite his illegitimate birth and flaws, was used by God to deliver Israel (Judges 11:1-11). This aligns with biblical teaching that God often chooses weak or rejected vessels to manifest His power (1 Corinthians 1:27-29; 2 Corinthians 12:9), emphasizing grace and divine empowerment rather than human merit.

questions.question: What does the Spirit of the LORD coming upon Jephthah indicate about the role of the Holy Spirit in Old Testament leadership?
options: The Spirit empowered leaders to accomplish God's will
The Spirit was absent in the Old Testament
The Spirit only gave prophetic visions
The Spirit condemned leaders
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit empowered leaders to accomplish God's will
questions.explanation: The Spirit's coming upon Jephthah (Judges 11:29) shows that the Holy Spirit empowered leaders for specific tasks in the Old Testament (Judges 3:10; 1 Samuel 16:13), prefiguring the New Testament fullness of the Spirit's work in believers (Acts 1:8; Romans 8:11). This affirms the Spirit's continuous role in God's redemptive plan.

questions.question: How does Jephthah's interaction with the king of Ammon reflect God's justice and judgment among nations?
options: Jephthah appeals to God's previous dispossession of the Amorites as justification for Israel's war
Jephthah claims Israel's superiority based on wealth
Jephthah accuses the king of Ammon of idolatry
Jephthah offers to share the land peacefully
questions.correctAnswer: Jephthah appeals to God's previous dispossession of the Amorites as justification for Israel's war
questions.explanation: Jephthah argues that the LORD dispossessed the Amorites for Israel, implying divine sanction for the land possession and judgment on enemies (Judges 11:21-24). This aligns with biblical themes of God as Judge of nations (Psalm 9:8; Romans 13:1), demonstrating His sovereignty over history and fulfillment of covenant promises.

questions.question: What doctrinal truth is highlighted by Jephthah's reliance on the LORD as witness to his leadership covenant?
options: God as the ultimate judge and witness over human agreements
Human oaths are sufficient without God's involvement
Leadership depends on popular vote
God does not concern Himself with earthly matters
questions.correctAnswer: God as the ultimate judge and witness over human agreements
questions.explanation: Jephthah calls the LORD to be witness to the covenant with the elders (Judges 11:10), underscoring God's role as the ultimate judge and witness (Hebrews 6:16-17; Psalm 89:14), affirming the seriousness of promises made before Him and His sovereign authority over human affairs.
